14.text:
Scarborough really is the ‘Queen of Seaside
Resorts’. It's the place which has got

19.text:
the lot. Not just one, but two wide sandy
bays - perfect for swimming. Then there’s

25.text:
the harbour with fishing boats and pleasure
boats bobbing about on the waves. And, of

29.text:
course, inevitably, I suppose, there are also
rows of amusement arcades. But there’s more

34.text:
to Scarborough than all this; it’s also
a place stuffed with historical interest.

39.text:
The 12th century castle over there on the
headland, makes that point.

44.text: The great headland which overlooks both north and south bays at Scarborough has probably ben a fortified

50.text:
location since the Iron Age. Certainly, the
Romans had a signal station here. And in 1154

56.text:
when King Henry II came to the throne he was
the one who ordered that the castle should

61.text:
be built. Well, it last saw action during
the First World War when it was shelled by

66.text:
the Germans, but all this isn’t down to
them - its been a ruin since 1645.

74.text:
1645 wasn’t a great year for St Mary’s church either:
it was the height of the English Civil War.

80.text:
In the fighting the choir aisle was destroyed
and the central tower collapsed. It means

85.text:
that the church we see today is much reduced
in size. Incidentally, perhaps one should

89.text:
also say, that at various times Scarborough
has also been home to three Orders of monks.

93.text:
The White Friars, the Black Friars and the
Grey Friars. But none of them survived King

97.text: Henry VIII and the dissolution of their monasteries.

103.text: So, the administrative and spiritual centre of the town

105.text: is up there on the hillside. But down here in this area, has always been about

110.text: commerce. By commerce, of course, I mean, fishing. And, if you look over there, well the great harbour

115.text:
walls they were built to protect the Scarborough
fishing fleet from North Sea storms. Now the

121.text:
industry is still going strong today, even
though it is under incredible financial pressure.

126.text:
But before Sandside was built - now that’s the
road which follows the beach round; they actually

130.text:
used to build the fishing boats down here
as well - 169 in 1797 alone.

137.text: But, by then, something even more important had been discovered up the other end of the bay.

148.text: Namely, water! In 1626, a certain Mrs Farrer was walking along the beach when she noticed a natural

154.text:
spring rising through the magnesium rocks.
Well, eventually the people of Scarborough

158.text: began to say to themselves: ‘Hang on; Harrogate's got natural spring water -

161.text: first discovered in 1571; and it’s doing ok out of it. Perhaps we could attract the rich and the famous

166.text:
to come here as well’. Well, it did take
them some time to get round to doing anything

170.text:
about it. It wasn’t 'til the 18th century
that Scarborough began saying to people:

174.text: ‘Why not take a dip in the sea? It’s very good for you'. But, in 1735, Scarborough introduced

180.text:
the very first bathing machine to protect
the modesty of those wanted to take a plunge.

186.text: So, perhaps the town has got good cause to claim that it really was the very first seaside resort.

193.text:
Well you can’t get spa water anymore
here in Scarborough. And, indeed, the Spa

197.text:
complex itself has had a chequered history.
In its time its been washed away by the sea;

202.text:
its collapsed in a landslide; and, in 1876,
it was burned down. But now this Spa has been

209.text:
lovingly restored and may visitors choose
to come here in the morning to read the paper,

213.text: have a cup of coffee, and listen to the Spa orchestra.

221.text: By the mid 1900s Scarborough really was the place to be seen.

224.text: It was a fashionable resort attracting visitors from all over the country.

228.text:
And it was about that time that streets,
here on the Esplanade, were laid out in a

233.text:
grid which centred on the Crown Hotel over
there.

240.text: In 1827, this bridge was built to link the Esplanade

244.text:
with the rest of the town. It
meant that visitors no longer had to scramble

248.text:
down the ravine and up the other side, when
they wanted to get into the centre of Scarborough.

252.text:
One of the other places they might have been
going, of course, was the Rotunda, over here.

265.text:
The Rotunda was built in 1829 to house the geological
samples and collections of William Smith.

273.text:
This building? Well, that is the Grand Hotel.
It was completed in 1867 and it has 365 rooms,

280.text:
and it stretches over 13 floors. Now it was built
to accommodate the visitors who flocked in

285.text:
once the railway link from York was completed
in 1845. Indeed, on the day the first train

290.text:
arrived, the 1st July 1845, 1,000 visitors
arrived in Scarborough. It was half the number

296.text: who had been here the whole season in the previous year.

299.text: Truly, the age of mass tourism had arrived.

310.text:
As the number of visitors
to Scarborough grew, so did the attractions

314.text:
designed to keep them amused. Perhaps even
more important, to persuade them to keep coming

318.text:
back. So, in 1912, Peasholm Park was laid
out. It includes this beautiful lake. Now

325.text:
on occasions here, grown men will squeeze
themselves into model warships to fight the

331.text: mother and father of all battles!

340.text: Meanwhile, on the opposite side of the road to Peasholm Park,

343.text:
there's the largest open air theatre in Europe,
with seating for over 10,000 people. Recent

349.text: artists to perform here include Elton John.

353.text: So, we come to the end of our visit to Scarborough,

356.text:
the biggest town on the Yorkshire coast. And,
of course, Scarborough’s fame has been spread

360.text:
even further, thanks to the Simon & Garfunkel
song ‘Scarborough Fair’. Now the song,

365.text:
or rather the poem, on which it is based, contains
the words ‘Between salt water and the sea

370.text:
strand’. So, why don’t we now go up the strand
- or the beach - just a bit to one of the smallest

375.text:
places on the Yorkshire coast, the village
of Staithes which nestles right on the Yorkshire/Cleveland border.
